instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Board had a bit of corrosion on <RESISTOR>R5005</RESISTOR> other than that rest of board is clean.

PPBUS 12.2V
PP3V42 1.7V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 1.7V
<RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> OK

First reballed SMC same thing, then replaced it same thing and also replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> was replaced also, <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>-96, <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR>-02 OK removed <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> all that and still no power or green light, any help will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Did you check <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> once SMC was removed?

Post all <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages and diode mode to ground at L7095.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
I did not check it, will note that for next time.

L7095 Diode reading 321

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>:
1 - 1.3V
2 - 1.9V
3 - 4.3V
4 - 1.9V

5 GND
6 - 16V
7 - 0V
8 - 16V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Replace <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure to have good solders and traces around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] Board is back, same problem, after removing it from case board sometimes starts up but with pp2v32 low at around 3.1V when board doesn't boot pp3v32 is around 3V even, removing <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> helped apparently but eventually same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Change all resistors and capacitors related with <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.
